doc.ContractDescription: SWEPT TIME-SPACE DOMAIN DECOMPOSITION RULE FOR BREAKING THE LATENCY BARRIER IN 20 YEARS, ENGINEERS WILL NOT SIMPLY BE DOING CFD ANALYSIS. THEY'LL BE SITTING AND DOING HIGH-FIDELITY DESIGN USING COMPUTATIONAL METHODS AND INCORPORATING CFD INTO THE DESIGN, ALMOST IN REAL TIME. J. SLOTNICK, AUTHOR OF NASA CFD-2030. OUR OBJECTIVE IS TO MAKE HIGH-FIDELITY CFD FAST ENOUGH FOR REAL-TIME DESIGN. A FUNDAMENTAL BARRIER TO THIS IS THE LATENCY BETWEEN LEVELS OF THE PARALLEL MEMORY HIERARCHY THAT LIMITS THE PERFORMANCE OF TIME-STEP SCHEMES AND ITERATIVE SOLUTION METHODS. WE PROPOSE THE SWEPT TIME-SPACE DECOMPOSITION RULE TO BYPASS THIS BARRIER. THE DECOMPOSED DOMAINS HAVE BOUNDARIES IN SPACE AND TIME THAT MATCH THE DOMAINS OF DEPENDENCY AND INFLUENCE OF THE GOVERNING NAVIER-STOKES PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS. THE RESULTING SWEPT DECOMPOSITION ENABLES EACH COMPUTING NODE TO ADVANCE MANY TIME STEPS OR PERFORM MANY ITERATIONS BEFORE HAVING TO COMMUNICATE WITH ITS NEIGHBORS, THEREBY BREAKING THE LATENCY BARRIER. TODAY'S WELL-UNDERSTOOD CFD ALGORITHMS AND SOFTWARE WILL HAVE TO BE REWRITTEN OR OVERHAULED TO WORK ON MASSIVELY PARALLEL COMPUTERS.W. GROPP, AUTHOR OF NASA CFD-2030. WE PROPOSE TO DEVELOP THE SWEPT DECOMPOSITION RULE INTO AN API THAT MAKES IT EASY TO REWRITE AN EXISTING CFD CODE. THE API SEPARATES IMPLEMENTATION OF NUMERICAL SCHEMES ON A SPACE-TIME GRID (VOLUME OR ELEMENT) FROM THE CODE THAT ORCHESTRATES THEIR EXECUTION AND HANDLES COMMUNICATIONS. THE FORMER PART CAN BE AGNOSTIC OF COMPUTER ARCHITECTURE, AND THEREFORE CAN FOCUS ON THE PHYSICS AND NUMERICAL ACCURACY. THE LATTER IS AGNOSTIC OF PDE AND NUMERICAL SCHEME, AND THEREFORE CAN BE OPTIMIZED FOR NEXT GENERATION COMPUTER ARCHITECTURE. THIS SEPARATION IS ESSENTIAL IN ORDER TO ACHIEVE MAXIMUM PERFORMANCE ON INCREASINGLY PREVALENT HETEROGENEOUS HPC ARCHITECTURES. THE SWEPT DECOMPOSITION SCHEME MUST BE ADVANCED BEYOND SIMPLY MPI PARALLELISM TO MPI+X, WHERE X REFERS TO A GPU OR OTHER PARALLEL COPROCESSOR (E.G., INTEL XEON PHI). HOWEVER, SUCH STREAMING PROCESSORS INTRODUCE ADDITIONAL COMPLEXITY THAT REQUIRES SIGNIFICANT ALGORITHMIC DESIGN CONSIDERATIONS. THIS WILL BE ACHIEVED THROUGH AN ADDITIONAL SPACE-TIME DECOMPOSITION LEVEL WITHIN THE GPU THAT CAN TAKE ADVANTAGE OF ITS MULTIPLE MEMORY HIERARCHIES. OPTIMAL PROCESSING AND MEMORY CONFIGURATIONS WILL BE EXPLORED THROUGH BOTH STATIC AND DYNAMIC ANALYSIS METHODS. FURTHERMORE, SINCE THE SWEPT DECOMPOSITION SCHEME ALLOWS SIGNIFICANT LOCAL CALCULATIONS BETWEEN ANY COMMUNICATION, THE CPU AND GPU ON A NODE WILL PERFORM CALCULATIONS SIMULTANEOUSLY UNLIKE NEARLY ALL EXISTING GPU-ACCELERATED CFD APPROACHES AVOIDING ANY WASTED RESOURCES. MOREOVER, MODERN AEROSPACE CFD RELIES ON 3D UNSTRUCTURED MESHES. THERE IS A STRONG RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN ANALYZING UNSTRUCTURED MESHES, GRAPH THEORY, AND SPARSE MATRIX ALGORITHMS. IN THE CONTEXT OF THIS PROPOSAL, WE WILL DESIGN A GRAPH THEORETICAL CHARACTERIZATION OF THE DECOMPOSED SPACE-TIME SUBDOMAINS THAT WILL SEAMLESSLY GENERALIZE THE RESULTS ON STRUCTURED MESHES TO UNSTRUCTURED MESHES. THE PROPOSED CHARACTERIZATION IS BASED ON A NOTION OF TRUNCATED BREADTH-FIRST SEARCHES THAT MODEL THE SET OF REACHABLE SPATIOTEMPORAL LOCATIONS. IT WILL BE EQUALLY APPLICABLE TO PARALLEL TIME INTEGRATION AND TO ITERATIVE SOLUTION METHODS. THE PROPOSED RESEARCH WILL DEVELOP SOLUTION TECHNIQUES BASED ON THE SWEPT DECOMPOSITION RULE FOR THE NAVIER-STOKES EQUATIONS THAT SIGNIFICANTLY INCREASE EFFICIENCY (POTENTIALLY MULTIPLE ORDERS OF MAGNITUDE) ON CURRENT AND FUTURE HPC SYSTEMS. PRELIMINARY RESULTS HAVE BROKEN THE LATENCY BARRIER BY A FACTOR OF 10 WHEN SOLVING A 1D EULER EQUATION USING A SECOND-ORDER SHOCK-CAPTURING FINITE VOLUME SCHEME. BY ELIMINATING THE LATENCY BARRIER IN LARGE-SCALE PARALLEL CFD SIMULATIONS, WE WILL MAKE SIGNIFICANT PROGRESS MOVING TOWARDS THE GRAND CHALLENGE OF REAL-TIME DESIGN OF AEROSPACE SYSTEMS.

doc.ContractDescription: PROJECT OBJECTIVES: THE PROPOSED RESEARCH WILL PROVIDE MEASUREMENTS OF KEY TRACE GASES IN THE ATMOSPHERE (CO2, CH4, N2O, CO) FROM SUB ORBITAL PLATFORMS (GLOBAL HAWK, WB57F, ER 2, DC 8) USING ADVANCED INSTRUMENTS ALREADY DEMONSTRATED IN FLIGHT. WE WILL ANALYZE DATA AND PRESENT SCIENTIFIC RESULTS USING ATMOSPHERIC MODELS AND PROVIDE DATA TO, AND COLLABORATE WITH, SCIENCE TEAMS FROM NASA AND OTHER AGENCIES IN MAJOR FIELD INVESTIGATIONS. IN A COMPLEMENTARY EFFORT, WE WILL UTILIZE INEXPENSIVE, MOVABLE SUNVIEWING FOURIER TRANSFORM SPECTROMETERS FOR CALIBRATION VALIDATION OF TOTAL COLUMN SATELLITE SENSORS SUCH AS OCO 2 AND GOSAT, COMPLEMENTING THE TCCON NETWORK. METHODS AND TECHNIQUES: WE HAVE THREE HIGHLY EXPERIENCED SENSORS: TWO NDIR AIRBORNE BALLOON CO2 SENSORS, AND THE 4 CHANNEL QUANTUM CASCADE LASER SPECTROMETER (QCLS) THAT MEASURED THE HIGH PRIORITY TRACER SUITE (CO2, CH4 N2O, AND CO) ON THE GLOBAL HIAPER POLE TO POLE OBSERVATIONS EXPERIMENT ("HIPPO", LOGGING 800 HOURS ON THE NCAR G V). OUR NDIR SENSORS HAVE PROVIDED RELIABLE, ACCURATE MEASUREMENTS ON THE ER 2, WB57F, PROTEUS, UWYO KING AIR, UND CITATION 2, AND OMS BALLOONS. WE HAVE ADDED A 3 CHANNEL CAVITY RINGDOWN SPECTROMETER (HU PCRDS, MEASURING CO2, CO, CH4), SUCCESSFULLY FLYING IN NASAS CARBON IN THE ARCTIC VULNERABILITY EXPERIMENT (CARVE). WE ARE PREPARING A HIGH ALTITUDE CRDS FOR THE UPCOMING SEAC4RS AND ATTREX MISSIONS (ER 2 AND GLOBAL HAWK, RESPECTIVELY). OUR MODELS INCLUDE AGE OF AIR ANALYSIS FOR INFERRING TIME SCALES OF TRANSPORT IN THE UPPER ATMOSPHERE, AND LAGRANGIAN PARTICLE DISPERSION MODELS (LPDMS) FOR ANALYZING SOURCES AND SINKS OF TRACE GASES. SIGNIFICANCE: WE WILL HELP ADDRESS ALL OF THE TOP SCIENTIFIC QUESTIONS FOR NASA S ATMOSPHERIC COMPOSITION FOCUS AREA: HOW IS ATMOSPHERIC COMPOSITION CHANGING? WHAT TRENDS IN ATMOSPHERIC CONSTITUENTS DRIVE GLOBAL CLIMATE? HOW DO ATMOSPHERIC TRACE CONSTITUENTS RESPOND TO AND AFFECT GLOBAL ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGE? WHAT ARE THE EFFECTS OF GLOBAL ATMOSPHERIC CHEMICAL AND CLIMATE CHANGES ON REGIONAL AIR QUALITY? HOW WILL FUTURE CHANGES IN ATMOSPHERIC COMPOSITION AFFECT OZONE, CLIMATE, AND GLOBAL AIR QUALITY? APPROACH: WE WILL PROVIDE THE FOLLOWING RESEARCH AND DATA PRODUCTS. 1. HIGH ACCURACY 1 HZ DATA FOR CO, CH4, AND CO2 FROM 1000 TO 50 MB IN CARVE, SEAC4RS, ATTREX AND FUTURE MISSIONS TO (A) DETERMINE TRANSPORT RATES INTO, WITHIN, AND OUT OF THE UPPER TROPOSPHERE LOWER STRATOSPHERE (UT LS) AND TROPICAL TROPOPAUSE LAYER (TTL) AND TO (B) CALIBRATE AND VALIDATE AURA AND OCO SATELLITES. 2. ANALYSIS OF IN SITU TRACERS TO DETERMINE THE AVERAGE SOURCE LOCATIONS FOR AIR IN THE TTL AND LS, AND TO DIAGNOSE TRANSPORT RATES AND PATHWAYS FOR SHORT LIVED REACTIVE SPECIES AND H2O. BECAUSE OR MEASUREMENTS ARE TIGHTLY TIED TO STANDARDS OF THE GLOBAL WMO SURFACE NETWORK, WE CAN DISTINGUISH AIR ORIGINATING FROM THE NEAR-SURFACE ENVIRONMENT OVER LAND OR SEA, FROM TROPICAL, MIDLATITUDE, OR BOREAL ZONES, OR FROM THE UPPER TROPOSPHERE, BY BOTH DIRECT MEASUREMENTS AND BY MODEL ANALYSIS. 3. CONSTRAINTS ON RATES FOR VERTICAL TRANSPORT IN CONVECTIVE EVENTS, AND THE ADMIXTURE OF BOUNDARY LAYER AIR INTO THE TTL/UT/LS. OUR TRACERS ARE STRATIFIED VERTICALLY AND VERY SEASONALLY AND WITH LATITUDE, AND HENCE THE ENSEMBLE PROVIDES FINGERPRINTS OF THE BOUNDARY LAYER AIR THAT MAY BE ENTRAINED AS UPDRAFTS IN A CONVECTIVE STORM. AS MEMBERS OF SCIENCE TEAMS ASSEMBLED FOR MISSIONS THAT NASA SPONSORS OR PARTICIPATES IN, OUR GROUP CONTRIBUTES COMPREHENSIVE, ACCURATE, RELIABLE TRACER DATA TO PROVIDE THE FOUNDATION FOR ANALYSIS OF THE OBSERVATIONS BY THE ENTIRE TEAM.

doc.ContractDescription: IGF::CT::IGF FOR CRITICAL FUNCTIONS - EXPERT SERVICES

STAR FORMATION, IN BOTH ITS NORMAL AND ACTIVE BURST PHASES, DRIVES AND IS DRIVEN BY THE PHYSICAL CONDITIONS IN GALAXIES THAT ARE FORMING STARS, FROM MASSIVE OUTFLOWS TO THE HEATING OF DUST. IT ALSO GOVERNS THE EVOLUTION OF METALLICITY, ENRICHMENT OF THE IGM, AND MANY OTHER PROCESSES. TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE PHYSICAL CONDITIONS THAT INITIATE - AND QUENCH - STAR FORMATION, INCLUDING ITS APPARENT SYMBIOTIC RELATIONSHIP WITH AGN ACTIVITY IN LATER-STAGE MERGERS, WE PROPOSE THE FIRST LARGE AND COHERENT RADIATIVE TRANSFER STUDY OF THE EXTREME OBJECTS THAT ARE FORMING STARS MOST RAPIDLY: THE LUMINOUS AND ULTRALUMINOUS INFRARED GALAXIES (LIRGS AND ULIRGS). OUR STUDY WILL BE BASED ON RADIATIVE TRANSFER MODELING OF ALL (U)LIRGS WITH RELIABLE ARCHIVAL HERSCHEL/SPIRE AND PACS MOLECULAR SPECTRA. OUR GOALS ARE TO (1) MODEL THE CONDITIONS IN THE DENSE CIRCUMNUCLEAR GAS CLOUDS AS A FUNCTION OF LFIR, M(H2), AND MERGER STAGE, AND TO DERIVE STAR FORMATION RATES (SFR), RADIATION PRESSURE, DUST AND GAS TEMPERATURES, OPTICAL DEPTHS, AND GAS DEPLETION RATES; (2) UNDERSTAND THE NUCLEAR MOLECULAR OUTFLOW/INFLOW PHENOMENA AND HOW AND WHY THEY DIFFER FOR LIRGS (LOG[LIR/LSUN]>11) AND ULIRGS (LOG[LIR/LSUN]>12); AND (3) TEST THE REALITY OF THE TWO PUTATIVE MODES OF STAR FORMATION (MAIN SEQUENCE AND STARBURST) AS A FUNCTION OF GALAXY LUMINOSITY AND MERGER STAGE, QUANTIFY THE DIFFERENCES, AND REVEAL THE PHYSICAL CAUSES (MERGER PROPERTIES, IMF DIFFERENCES, ETC.)
doc.MajorAgency: THE PHYSICAL AND CHEMICAL CONDITIONS IN LUMINOUS G
doc.MajorFundingAgency: THE PHYSICAL AND CHEMICAL CONDITIONS IN LUMINOUS G

doc.ContractDescription: USING AIRCRAFT STRATOSPHERIC WATER VAPOR MEASUREMENTS COUPLED WITH COMPLEMENTARY SATELLITE DATA, GROUNDBASED RADAR AND MODEL RESULTS TO STUDY THE INFLUENCE OF DEEP CONVECTION OVER NORTH AMERICA WE WILL PURSUE THREE RESEARCH TASKS, COMBINING IN SITU AIRCRAFT AND GOUND-BASED DATA, SATELLITE DATA, AND REGIONAL MODELING, IN ORDER TO IDENTIFY AND QUANTIFY SOURCES OF WATER VAPOR IN THE UPPER TROPOSPHERE AND LOWER STRATOSPHERE OVER NORTH AMERICA AND VALIDATE A METHOD FOR THE PREDICTION OF HOW THE SOURCES ARE EXPECTED TO CHANGE WITH GLOBAL WARMING. WATER VAPOR IN THE MID-LATITUDE UPPER TROPOSPHERE AND LOWER STRATOSPHERE PLAYS A STRONG ROLE IN THE RADIATIVE FORCING OF BOTH THE TROPOSPHERIC CLIMATE AND STRATOSPHERIC CLIMATE. FURTHERMORE, ENHANCED WATER VAPOR IN THE LOWER STRATOSPHERE OVER NORTH AMERICA MAY WELL FOSTER THE CATALYTIC DESTRUCTION OF OZONE, IMPACTING PUBLIC HEALTH. WE PAY CLOSE ATTENTION ESPECIALLY TO THE DIRECT INJECTION OF WATER VAPOR INTO THE LOWER STRATOSPHERE BY DEEP CONVECTION IN NORTH AMERICA, EVIDENCE FOR WHICH HAS ALREADY BEEN FOUND IN AIRCRAFT MEASUREMENTS OF WATER VAPOR AND ITS ISOTOPOLOGUES AS WELL AS NEXT GENERATION WEATHER RADAR NEXRAD OBSERVATIONS. IN THE FIRST RESEARCH TASK WE WILL IDENTIFY AND QUANTIFY THE SOURCES OF WATER VAPOR IN THE NORTH AMERICAN STRATOSPHERE USING CHEMICAL TRACER DATA OBTAINED IN SEVERAL NASA FLIGHT CAMPAIGNS. EACH OF FOUR DIFFERENT SOURCES THE BREWER DOBSON CIRCULATION, ISENTROPIC MIXING BY BAROCLINIC EDDIES FROM THE SUBTROPICS, ISENTROPIC TRANSPORT BY THE ANTICYCLONIC MONSOON CIRCULATION, AND EXTREMELY DEEP MOIST CONVECTION CONTAINS A UNIQUE FINGERPRINT IN CHEMICAL TRACER AND WATER ISOTOPE DATA. EVERY AIR PARCEL SAMPLED IN A FLIGHT CAMPAIGN CAN BE DESCRIBED AS A LINEAR COMBINATION OF THE FINGERPRINTS THAT QUANTIFY EACH SOURCE. THE ANDERSON GROUP HAS PREVIOUSLY DEMONSTRATED THIS METHOD IN THE PEER-REVIEWED LITERATURE. IN THE SECOND RESEARCH TASK WE WILL IDENTIFY THE SOURCES OF FIVE INSTANCES OF GREATLY ELEVATED CONCENTRATIONS OF WATER VAPOR IN THE LOWER STRATOSPHERE OVER NORTH AMERICA. THESE FIVE CASES ALREADY SHOW EVIDENCE OF DEEP CONVECTION AS THEIR SOURCE, AND WE WILL PERFORM TRAJECTORY CALCULATIONS TO LINK THESE CASES TO SPECIFIC DEEP CONVECTIVE EVENTS. THE CONVECTIVE EVENTS THEMSELVES WILL BE IDENTIFIED IN RADAR DATA AND IN SATELLITE THERMAL INFRARED IMAGERY. A MONTE CARLO TRAJECTORY ANALYSIS WILL NOT ONLY ENABLE AN ATTRIBUTION STUDY COMPLETE WITH A STATISTICAL ESTIMATE OF UNCERTAINTY, IT WILL ALSO PERMIT AN INFERENCE OF THE TOTAL MASS OF WATER VAPOR INJECTED BY THE DEEP CONVECTION EVENTS INTO THE LOWER STRATOSPHERE. THE RADAR AND INFRARED IMAGERY HAVE ALREADY BEEN DEMONSTRATED AS TOOLS TO DETECT MID LATITUDE CONVECTION THAT PENETRATES INTO THE LOWER STRATOSPHERE. IN THE THIRD RESEARCH TASK WE WILL VALIDATE THE ADVANCED RESEARCH WRF ARW AS A TOOL THAT CAN BE USED TO BUDGET THE SOURCES OF LOWER STRATOSPHERIC WATER VAPOR OVER NORTH AMERICA AND TO PREDICT HOW THE SOURCES, ESPECIALLY DEEP CONVECTION, CAN BE EXPECTED TO CHANGE WITH GLOBAL WARMING. AT PRESENT, ONLY DEEP CONVECTION AS A SOURCE FOR LOWER STRATOSPHERIC WATER VAPOR CANNOT BE RESOLVED IN GLOBAL CLIMATE MODELS, AND REGIONAL, CONVECTION RESOLVING MODELS HAVE ALREADY DEMONSTRATED A CAPABILITY TO GENERATE CONVECTION THAT PENETRATES INTO THE LOWER STRATOSPHERE. WE WILL INVESTIGATE THE MORPHOLOGY AND CLIMATOLOGY OF THE DEEP CONVECTION GENERATED BY ARW AND WHETHER IT GENERATES MORE CONVECTION OVER NORTH AMERICA THAN OVER THE INDIAN SUBCONTINENT IN AUGUST 2007 AS IS EVIDENT IN SATELLITE DATA. THIS PROJECT IS RELEVANT TO THE NASA EARTH SCIENCE RESEARCH FOCUS AREAS PERTAINING TO ATMOSPHERIC COMPOSITION AND TO CLIMATE VARIABILITY AND CHANGE. MOREOVER, IT DIRECTLY RESPONDS TO THE ATMOSPHERIC COMPOSITION CAMPAIGN DATA ANALYSIS AND MODELING CALL BY ADDRESSING TRENDS IN ATMOSPHERIC COMPOSITION RELATED TO RADIATIVE FORCING AND TO TRENDS IN STRATOSPHERIC OZONE CONCENTRATION. THE RESEARCH TEAM CONSTITUTED OF MEMBERS OF THE ANDERSON GROUP (HA

doc.ContractDescription: HELM CONSOLE (LSD 41/49 CLASS)
COUPLER,ROTARY,RADI
SHADES FOR JP

THE PRESENT MODIS STANDARD PRODUCTS FOR THE OCEANS INCLUDE THE ABOVE-SURFACE PHOTOSYNTHETIC AVAILABLE RADIATION (PAR(0+)) AND THE DIFFUSE ATTENUATION COEFFICIENT AT 490 NM (KD(490)). THEY ARE VALUABLE FOR MANY STUDIES, BUT ARE NOT ADEQUATE FOR THE ESTIMATION OF SOLAR RADIATION IN THE UPPER WATER COLUMN. THIS IS MAINLY BECAUSE: 1) THE TRANSMITTANCE OF LIGHT FROM ABOVE SURFACE TO BELOW SURFACE IS NOT A CONSTANT, BUT VARIES WITH LOCATION AND TIME; 2) KD(490), A SINGLE WAVELENGTH PRODUCT, CANNOT BE USED TO CALCULATE THE VERTICAL ATTENUATION OF PAR (A BROAD BAND PRODUCT); AND 3) PAR(0+) REPRESENTS DAILY TOTAL RADIATION, WHILE KD(490) (AND THE EVALUATION KD(PAR) PRODUCT) REPRESENTS AN INSTANTANEOUS ATTENUATION. BECAUSE THE LIGHT ATTENUATION COEFFICIENT ALSO VARIES DIURNALLY, A COMBINATION OF DAILY PAR(0+) AND INSTANTANEOUS KD(PAR) WILL RESULT IN SIGNIFICANT (CAN BE A FACTOR OF 2 OR 3, AS IT IS DEPTH DEPENDENT) ERRORS IN THE ESTIMATED PAR AT DEPTH. SEPARATELY, THE PRIMARY PRODUCTION (PP) VALUES OF THE GLOBAL OCEANS ESTIMATED FROM THE TRADITIONAL CHLOROPHYLL-BASED APPROACHES CONTAIN SIGNIFICANT UNCERTAINTIES, WHICH MAKE THE CURRENT SATELLITE-DERIVED WATER-COLUMN PP UNRELIABLE FOR THE ASSESSMENT OF SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL VARIATIONS. MAINLY THE UNCERTAINTY ARISES FROM THE LARGE SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL VARIATION OF CHLOROPHYLL-SPECIFIC ABSORPTION COEFFICIENT (A*PH), WHICH IS REQUIRED, EXPLICITLY OR IMPLICITLY, FOR THE RETRIEVAL OF CHLOROPHYLL-A CONCENTRATION FROM WATER COLOR AND FOR THE ESTIMATION OF BIOMASS-NORMALIZED PHOTOSYNTHETIC EFFICIENCY. IT HAS LONG BEEN ARGUED THAT IT IS NECESSARY TO TAKE AN APPROACH THAT ESTIMATES PP WITHOUT THE ENGAGEMENT OF A*PH. TO OVERCOME THE LIMITATIONS LISTED ABOVE, AND MORE IMPORTANTLY TO MAXIMIZE THE VALUE OFFERED BY MODIS TERRA/AQUA FOR OCEAN PHYSICAL AND BIOGEOCHEMICAL STUDIES, WE WILL DEVELOP AND REFINE NEW ALGORITHMS FOR THE GENERATION OF THESE NEW PRODUCTS FROM MODIS OCEAN-COLOR MEASUREMENTS: 1) SUB-SURFACE, DAILY, USABLE SOLAR RADIATION (USR), 2) DIFFUSE ATTENUATION COEFFICIENT OF USR (K(USR)), AND 3) DAILY, WATER-COLUMN PRIMARY PRODUCTION (PPEU). USR IS DEFINED AS THE SOLAR RADIATION IN THE SPECTRAL WINDOW OF 400-560 NM, A WINDOW THAT PENETRATES MOST IN THE GLOBAL OCEANS AND IS MOST SIGNIFICANT FOR PHYTOPLANKTON PHOTOSYNTHESIS. BECAUSE USR AND K(USR) PRODUCTS ARE CONSISTENT BOTH SPECTRALLY AND TEMPORALLY, IT WILL THEN BE STRAIGHTFORWARD, AND ACCURATE, TO ESTIMATE SOLAR RADIATION AT DEPTHS WHEN THE VALUES OF K(USR) AND SUBSURFACE USR ARE KNOWN. FURTHER, THE PROPOSED PPEU ESTIMATION WILL BE BASED ON THE FIRST PRINCIPLES OF PHYTOPLANKTON PHOTOPHYSIOLOGY AND LIGHT PENETRATION [BEHRENFELD 1998], I.E., IT WILL USE DIRECTLY THE ABSORPTION COEFFICIENT OF PHYTOPLANKTON FOR THE ESTIMATION OF ABSORBED PHOTONS, THUS BY-PASSING THE ENGAGEMENT OF A*PH WHEN USING CHLOROPHYLL CONCENTRATION. THE RESULTED PP PRODUCTS WILL THEN SIGNIFICANTLY IMPROVE THE SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL CHARACTERIZATIONS OF PPEU IN THE GLOBAL OCEANS. COMPLETION OF THIS PROJECT WILL NOT ONLY RESULT IN INNOVATIVE PRODUCTS DIRECTLY APPLICABLE TO STUDIES OF THE OCEAN S HEAT BUDGET AND PHOTOSYNTHESIS IN THE UPPER WATER COLUMN, BUT WILL ALSO BE IMPORTANT FOR INVESTIGATING PHOTO-OXIDATION AND PHYTOPLANKTON PHENOLOGY. THE PROJECT WILL FURTHER ENHANCE OUR CAPABILITIES IN MEETING NASA STRATEGIC SUB-GOAL 3A TO STUDY EARTH FROM SPACE TO ADVANCE SCIENTIFIC UNDERSTANDING AND MEET SOCIETAL NEEDS.
